title: Bengalore Drenches Under Torrential Rains as IMD Issues Yellow Alert for Heavy Downpour; Check Waterlogging-Affected Areas | Times Now
text: Bengaluru: The IT hub, is currently experiencing a series of torrential rains, leading to continuous in several parts of the city. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a yellow alert for Bangalore due to heavy rains, thunderstorms, and lightning. The city had been grappling with a dry spell that lasted over 160 days. Last night, the garden city experienced heavy rainfall in different parts throughout the night, resulting in waterlogging. One resident from Koramangala, who has lived in the city for six years, expressed her gratefulness for the current cool weather. "The heat was something I had never seen before. We never had to use an air conditioner here before, but this time, we did. I am so glad the famous Bangalore weather is back."Bengaluru Weather Forecast: Yellow Alert in BangaloreFor the upcoming week, IMD has predicted week-long rains. On May 9th, temperatures are expected to range between 22 degrees Celsius and 34 degrees Celsius, with the possibility of rain. May 10th and 11th will see similar conditions, with temperatures fluctuating between 23 degrees Celsius and 35 degrees Celsius. The trend continues on May 12th, with temperatures remaining within the 24 degrees Celsius to 35 degrees Celsius range and chances of rain persisting. So, be prepared for varying weather conditions and keep an umbrella handy to stay dry during possible showers. Waterlogging AreasHeavy rains have led to significant waterlogging in various areas, causing slow-moving traffic and inconvenience for commuters. The Bengaluru Traffic Police notified on their X handle about the areas that were waterlogged after heavy rains. The areas were Windsor Manor towards Old Highground Junction, Anil Kumble Circle towards BRV Junction, BEL Circle towards Hebbal, and Outer Ring Road from Pantarapalya towards Nayandahalli. Additionally, congestion on Airport Road from Chalukya Circle to Hebbal Flyover, at Sumanahalli Junction, Nayandahalli Junction, and along the Outer Ring Road from Hebbal to Gorguntepalya to Nayandahalli were reported by the authority.
